text: What is OAuth?

Ever logged into a new app using your Google, Facebook, or GitHub account without entering a password? That seamless login experience is powered by OAuth — an open standard protocol that lets you give apps limited access to your data without ever sharing your password.
OAuth (Open Authorization) is a secure way to authorize third-party applications to access your resources, like profile information, photos, or emails, without compromising your credentials.
Why Was OAuth Needed?

Before OAuth, the only way to give a third-party app access to your data was by giving them your username and password — a risky move! It meant apps had full access to your account and could act on your behalf indefinitely.
OAuth was designed to solve this by:
Avoiding password sharing
Granting limited and revocable access
Improving mobile and cross-platform compatibility
Simplifying secure access for third-party services
Real-Life Example: How OAuth Works
Let’s say Anna wants to print her photos stored on PixVault using a printing service called PrintEasy.
Here's how OAuth handles this securely:
Request Access: Anna tells PrintEasy to access her PixVault photos.
Authorization Request: PrintEasy asks PixVault (via the Authorization Server) for permission, sharing its identity and what kind of access it needs (scope).
User Consent: Anna logs into PixVault and approves PrintEasy's request.
Authorization Code: PixVault sends a temporary code back to PrintEasy.
Token Exchange: PrintEasy uses this code to get an Access Token from PixVault’s Authorization Server.
Secure Access: With the token, PrintEasy accesses only the photos Anna allowed — without ever seeing her login credentials.
OAuth Keeps Control in Your Hands
OAuth ensures:
Your password is never shared with the third-party app.
You can revoke access at any time.
Apps get access to only what they need — not your full account.
It also supports Refresh Tokens, which allow the app to renew access without bothering the user again.
Key Components of OAuth 2.0
To understand OAuth better, let’s break down its main players:
Resource Owner: You (the user) who owns the data.
Client: The third-party app that wants access (like PrintEasy).
Authorization Server: The gatekeeper that handles login and issues tokens.
Resource Server: The service (like PixVault) that holds your protected data.
What is an Access Token?
An Access Token is a digital key that lets an app access your data securely. It usually has an expiry time and limited permissions (defined by scopes).
Sometimes, a Refresh Token is also given, which helps the app request a new Access Token without needing your approval again.
Scopes in OAuth
Scopes define what the app can access. For example:
profile: Access to your basic profile
email: Permission to read your email address
photos.read: Only view your photos
The Authorization Server grants access only within the defined scope.
Authorization vs Authentication
Many people confuse authentication (who you are) with authorization (what you're allowed to do). OAuth handles the authorization part.
Example:
Authentication: Proving you are Anna (like logging into PixVault).
Authorization: Letting PrintEasy access just your photos — not your contacts or account settings.
OAuth is often paired with authentication protocols like SAML or OpenID Connect for full user management.
Summary
OAuth is a secure and flexible protocol for third-party authorization.
It lets users approve access without sharing passwords.
It works via tokens, scopes, and permission grants.
OAuth 2.0 is used by giants like Google, Facebook, GitHub, and more.
So next time you “Sign in with Google,” just know — OAuth is working behind the scenes to keep your data safe while giving apps just the right amount of access!
